tweet: @edwardrooster @NateElliott 4. Existing gas stations already have a whole bunch of utilities installed: water, electricity, fiber optic. So they become a nexus of new development that wants to be close to traffic flows.   2 pennis for my thoughts...

tweet: @edwardrooster @NateElliott Even if it's only to take a leak. But it might also be to buy a snack, charge up the battery, buy gas or something else.   3. It will be increasingly difficult to build new spurs onto highways - especially close to urban centers.

name: Guy Spier
tweet: @edwardrooster @NateElliott Nate, actually I think that they do pretty well.   1. Highways are not going anywhere.  2. So long as there are people driving somewhere (no matter if it's gas, electricity, hydrogen or other powered), people will want to stop for one reason or another.
